metadata.title: Dry Needling (DN)
description: Invasive procedure in which small, solid, filiform (fine filament) needles are inserted directly into skin and muscle without use of saline or other liquid agents in order to relieve myofascial trigger points (1,2,3)

DN is not acupuncture –This distinction remains controversial, as indicated by the position statement of the American Association of Acupuncture and Oriental Medicine in 2013, which states that TrP needling, intramuscular stimulation, or any other method by which a needle is inserted to effect therapeutic change is by definition acupuncture(19) -There continues to be controversy surrounding this topic, with many challenges to state physical therapy boards, primarily by acupuncture licensing boards(11) -As an example, on September 15, 2015, the North Carolina Acupuncture Licensing Board filed a lawsuit against the North Carolina Board of PT Examiners in Wake County Superior Court to “protect the public from the unlicensed practice of acupuncture by physical therapists offering ‘dry needling’”

CPT codes.There: are no CPT codes for DN –Intramuscular manual therapy is a term associated with DN; however, APTA does not endorse the use of the manual therapy CPT code (97140)(4)
CPT codes.97780: and 97781 are acupuncture codes and cannot be used by a physical therapist without an acupuncture license

reimbursement: DN is considered medically necessary for conservative treatment of some pathologies by some insurance companies, while others consider it experimental and under investigation. According to the APTA’s published guidelines for billing, “Practitioners who seek to bill any third party payer should first check the payer’s coverage policy to determine if dry needling is a covered service and if the policy specifies which code is used to report the service.”(26) Many PTs provide DN on a cash basis only(27) Indications for procedure
contraindications precautions to test: Signs of acute illness (e.g., fever, nausea, diarrhea)
Pain that is not reproduced from musculoskeletal structures
Pediatric patient without presence of and consent of parent/guardian
Findings suggestive of comorbidities requiring physician consultation

indications for procedure: An APTA resource paper on the clinical use of DN emphasizes that DN is one tool in a broad treatment approach and should be combined with other techniques (soft tissue mobilization, ROM, exercise, neuromuscular reeducation, etc.)(27)
DN is used for the treatment of neuromusculoskeletal pain and dysfunction, including MTrP pain and dysfunction, soft tissue pain, muscle tension, and scar tissue(54)

An MTrP is defined as a localized, hyperirritable spot in a nodule of skeletal muscle(5,6) consisting of an accumulation of sensitized nociceptors in the end plate zone of muscle fibers. Clinical characteristics of an MTrP are the following:(8) Palpable, taut band that can be snapped or rolled and contains a highly localized tender spot –Stimulation (e.g., compression, palpation, needling) of the band usually elicits a twitch response Limited ROM and increased sensitivity to stretch Characteristic referred pain pattern that is familiar to the patient Painful, weak, easily fatigued muscle with minimal or no measured or observable atrophy Associated sensory(8) (e.g., tenderness, reduced pain threshold, pain referral), autonomic(6) (e.g., local hyperthermia, referred hypothermia), and proprioceptive(6) (e.g., balance disturbance, weight perception, dizziness) phenomena

MTrP formation and classification(6,8) The generally accepted mechanism of MTrP formation is muscle trauma resulting from low-level,  sustained muscle contraction,(9) direct trauma,(8) or acute, repetitive, or chronic muscle overload from eccentric muscle contraction –The underlying trauma alters the motor endplate, leading to excessive acetylcholine release and local sustained contraction, resulting in ischemic changes and sensitization of peripheral nociceptors. This proposed explanation is called the integrated TrP hypothesis(6,8,10) MTrPs are classified as active or latent(5) –Active MTrPs are associated with spontaneous local or referred pain and/or pain on movement,(7) while latent TrPs require direct stimulation to trigger pain symptoms(8) Both active and latent MTrPs are associated with muscle dysfunction, including weakness, restricted ROM, and fatigability(6,8) Lowered pain threshold in muscle tissue is associated with both active and latent MTrPs MTrPs are associated with most, if not all, chronic pain syndromes(8)

contraindications ,: Bleeding disorder or current use of anticoagulant (including aspirin) therapy
Presence of local or systemic infection
Needling in vicinity of implanted devices
relative contraindications ,: Allergy to nickel or stainless steel (components of needle)
Anatomically sensitive areas–Pleura and lungs–Blood vessels–Organs–Nerves

Severe hyperalgesia or allodynia(4)–In patients with central sensitization there is an increased responsiveness to peripheral stimuli. New nociceptive stimulimay further sustain the process of central sensitization(21)
precautions ,: Observe infection-control  procedures–Wash hands–Prepare patient’s skin appropriately–Use single-use  needles-Dispose of needles appropriately
Wear appropriate protective equipment–Gloves-Confirm patient is not allergic to latex if using latex gloves–Mask, eye shield, gown, if desired
Safe handling of needles–Avoid contact with shaft of needle
Be prepared for removal of broken needles–Do not insert more than half of the needle(20)
Sharp stinging, burning, or electrical pain could signal penetration of a nerve or blood vessel, which should be avoided(20)
adverse effects: Researchers investigating the incidence of adverse events during TrP-DN  in a sample of 39 PTs in Ireland over a 10-monthperiod found that mild adverse effects occurred in 19.18% (1,463/7,629) of treatments, but no significant adverse eventsoccurred(31)–Common adverse effects were bruising, bleeding, pain during treatment, and pain after treatment

Possible adverse effects of DN–Soreness or pain after needling-The use of the spray and stretch method after DN was found to have a short-term  (< 6 hours) effect in reducingpost-needling  soreness of a latent MTrP in the upper trapezius muscle in an RCT conducted in the United States(29)–Local hemorrhage at the needling site-After needling, avoid placing pressure on the site for at least 2 minutes to decrease chance of bruising(20)–Sympathetic response, including sweating–Syncope (fainting) during treatment–Pneumothorax(30)

statutory issues: United States–DN has been formally included within the scope of physical therapy practice in the District of Columbia and in thefollowing states: Alabama, Alaska, Arizona, Colorado, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa,Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maryland, Mississippi, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Hampshire, New Mexico, NorthCarolina, North Dakota, Ohio, Rhode Island, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Vermont, Virginia,West Virginia, and Wyoming(11)-In Connecticut, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin, no formalstatements or opinions have been made but there is nothing in the practice acts of these states that would prohibit DN-Currently the only states that have made a ruling against dry needling being within the scope of practice for physicaltherapists are California, Hawaii, New Jersey, New York, Oregon and Washington , mainly due to verbiage in thepractice act against puncturing the skin
International–DN is within the scope of physiotherapy practice in Asia, Australia, Europe, South Africa, South America, New Zealand,and Canada
training: The FSBPT has identified a list of entry-level  and DN-specific knowledge and job-task  competencies(25)–DN-specific  tasks-Information gathering and synthesis-Identify prior experience with and tolerance for DN, identify contraindications and precautions to DN, and sequenceDN with other procedural interventions and techniques-Manual therapy techniques-Exposing area, reducing risk of harm, educating patient on impact of movement during treatment, palpation, needlehandling techniques, draping, DN techniques, managing needle removal complications, monitoring patient response,facilitating hemostasis as necessary, disposing of medical waste, discussing post-treatment  expectations-Education-Educate patient about DN, potential adverse effects, and precautions and contraindications for DN-Emergency procedures-Implement emergency response procedures to treat both patient and practitioner injuries sustained during DN-Environmental safety-Prepare and maintain a safe and comfortable environment and stock supplies and equipment in safe proximity duringtreatment-Infection control-Implement infection-control  procedures, clean and disinfect blood and bodily fluid spills, replace surfaces that cannotbe cleaned-Professional responsibilities-Determine own ability to perform DN safely and effectively–DN-specific  knowledge-Anatomy and physiology-Surface anatomy including variations in form, proportion, and anatomical landmarks-Emergency preparedness and response-Emergency preparedness and/or response procedures to secondary physiological or emotional effects or complicationsassociated with DN, and standards for needle handling-Safety and protection-Factors influencing safety and protection, personal protection procedures and techniques, theoretical basis for DN,theoretical basis for combining DN with other interventions, secondary effects or complications associated with DN,theoretical basis of pain sciences, contraindications/precautions related to DN, palpation techniques, needle insertiontechniques, needle manipulation techniques, physiological responses to DN, information about solid filament needles
successful dn requires: excellent palpation skills for locating MTrPs(2)
visualization of the location and depth of MTrPs within the relevant anatomic structures in three dimensions
kinesthetic perception necessary to–appreciate differences in the tissues penetrated by the needle(2)–distinguish among skin, subcutaneous tissue, muscle, taut bands within the muscle, fascia, etc.

Most clinical and research parameters are based on expert opinion(21)–In general, once an MTrP has been located, the overlying skin is cleansed with alcohol and the clinician pinches the TrPbetween thumb and index finger or between two fingers. A needle is inserted 1–2 cm from the TrP so that it approaches atapproximately a 30 ° angle to the skin(20)–DN involves a relatively slow, steady motion in and out of the muscle. The needle is brought out to the edge of themyofascia, then inserted back into the muscle repeatedly(20)–The aim is to elicit a local twitch response, an involuntary contraction of the fibers(20)

contraindications precautions to examina: Signs of acute illness (e.g., fever, nausea, diarrhea)
Pain that is not reproduced from musculoskeletal structures
Pediatric patient without presence of and consent of parent/guardian
Findings suggestive of comorbidities requiring physician consultation

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document mechanism and history of injury or events leading to current presentation. Note repetitive or postural stress factors -MTrP formation is associated with trauma

course of treatment.medical management: Describe current and past medical treatment for the current condition. Describe treatment of past similar conditions. Note success in relieving symptoms
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Are they effective?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Document diagnostic tests (e.g., EMG, MRI, ultrasound)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document factors that mitigate or increase symptoms as well as length of time any such factor requires before the symptoms come on or are eased
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document history of trauma or similar dysfunction/injury
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Document current work status and limitations, if any. Document participation in sports or other recreational activities as well as current limitations
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document any limitations in ADLs. Document use of equipment to assist patient during ADLs
social and occupational history.living environment: If applicable, document stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Patient body type should be noted. Relative difficulty in palpation of MTrPs, anatomic landmarks, and anatomic structures is of interest in assessing whether DN is an appropriate intervention tool
relevant tests and measures.balance: Document impairment in static and dynamic balance, if relevant
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Functional mobility –Assess patient’s ability to perform functional mobility
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait analysis to identify altered movement pattern, asymmetry, and speed should be conducted. The 6-minute  walk test can be administered to evaluate gait speed(24) Joint integrity and mobility –Articular dysfunction should be documented(6,14,15) Motor function (motor control/tone/learning) –Movement patterns should be examined. Deficits and asymmetries should be noted –Assess tone with the Modified Ashworth Scale(44)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Comprehensive manual muscle test (MMT) of the affected body areas should be conducted –Document pain associated with muscle contraction
observation inspection palpation includi: Detailed palpation to identify location of MTrPs should be conducted -MTrPs are identified by using either a flat palpation technique (e.g., palpation of infraspinatus, temporalis, lower trapezius) or a pincer-type palpation technique (e.g., palpation of sternocleidomastoid, upper trapezius, gastrocnemius)
Document referred pain patterns elicited by palpation
relevant tests and measures.posture: Static and dynamic posture should be examined and documented as part of a comprehensive movement pattern analysis
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Limitations in ROM and flexibility should be noted and correlated with other signs and symptoms(24,53)
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Pertinent reflex testing should be conducted and documentedDocument if relevant
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Pressure pain threshold (measured by algometer) can be used to identify MTrP location

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this procedure are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment in their assessment and treatment decisions

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or the specific protocols of the treatment clinic

Patients with a diagnosis for which this procedure is used may be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis/need for procedure Myofascial pain syndrome Pain syndromes associated with MTrPs
prognosis: Patients with myofascial pain have improved pain in the short term. Long-term  patient outcomes depend on DN protocol, disease characteristics, and patient demographic profile(16,17)
other considerations: Physiological mechanisms –Evidence about potential physiological effects of DN is lacking(21) -The mechanisms and effects of DN most likely differ depending on location of needle placement, depth of insertion, needle forces and motions used, and whether or not a local twitch response is elicited(21) -Central and peripheral networks are probably recruited, and responses may be both physiologic and psychologic(21) -Proposed mechanisms include effects on the taut band, effects on blood flow, effects on peripheral and central sensitization, segmental inhibition/gate control, release of endogenous opioids, and effects on the release of neurotransmitters such as serotonin and noradrenalin -The neural pathway for remote effects appears to be mediated via a spinal reflex -Placebo effects may also occur. Neuroimaging has demonstrated that expectancy can modulate analgesia at subcortical and cortical levels –In a study conducted in Poland, DN was found to cause intense vasodilation in the sciatic pain area when used on patients with active TrPs in the gluteus minimus who complained of subacute sciatica(31) -Vasodilation was measured by infrared thermovision technique in 50 patients, of whom 16 had active TrPs in the gluteus minimus -Significant increases in the thigh and calf temperature were noted only in patients with active TrPs -The authors suggested that this supports the idea that sympathetic nerve activity is involved in myofascial pain pathomechanism
treatment summary: Authors of a 2017 systematic review and meta-analysis  of the use of DN for musculoskeletal conditions by PTs found the following:(46) –Very low-quality  to moderate-quality  evidence that DN is more effective than no treatment, sham DN, and other treatments for reducing pain and improving pressure pain threshold in the immediate to 12-week  follow-up  period –Low-quality  evidence for superior outcomes with DN for functional outcomes when compared to no treatment or sham DN, but no difference in functional outcomes when compared to other physical therapy treatments –A lack of evidence of long-term  benefit of DN
Authors of a 2016 systematic review (N = 467) in the United States found mixed results on the effectiveness of DN compared to conventional rehabilitation for musculoskeletal pain and disability(41)

Lumbar spine DN may be an effective tool to treat perceived pain (measured by V AS) and MTrPs associated with low back pain (LBP).(47) Patients with increased LBP with the multifidus lift test and no aggravation with standing might demonstrate the most improved disability with DN treatment (as measured by Oswestry Disability Index)(32) –Authors of a 2018 systematic review and meta-analysis  found moderate evidence that DN of MTrPs, especially if associated with other therapies, can be recommended to relieve the intensity of LBP. The authors did point out that the superiority of DN in improving functional disability remains unclear(47) –Koppenhaver et al.(32) examined the associations between demographic, patient history, and physical examination variables and self-reported  disability (Oswestry Disability Index) after DN treatment and found increased LBP with the multifidus lift test to be the strongest predictor of improved disability after DN -Seventy-two  volunteers with mechanical LBP participated in this quasi-experimental  study conducted in the United States -Treatment consisted of 1 treatment of DN to bilateral lumbar multifidus muscles and improvement was based on percent change at 1 week -Other factors associated with improved disability were increased LBP during passive hip flexion while patient supine and positive beliefs about DN/acupuncture. Less improvement associated with pain with standing, presence of leg pain, and perception of hypermobility in the lumbar spine

Neck, shoulder, upper quarter –Authors of a 2015 systematic review and meta-analysis  of the effectiveness of DN for MTrP associated with neck and shoulder pain concluded that DN can be recommended for relieving MTrP pain in the short term (0–3 days) and the medium term(33) -Based on 20 RCTs involving 839 patients  -Authors also determined that other therapies (including physical therapy) were more effective in treating MTrP in the medium term –DN performed on the lower trapezius TrP was more effective at treating pain (measured by V AS and Neck Pain Questionnaire) and pressure-pain  threshold than DN to another area of the lower trapezius muscle(34) -Double-blind  RCT conducted in Spain -Seventy-two  patients with unilateral neck pain for ≥ 3 months and active trigger points in the lower trapezius were randomly assigned to either DN to lower trapezius TrP or DN to other area of lower trapezius muscle –One session of DN to the latent MTrP associated with the key active MTrP in the infraspinatus muscle reduced pain intensity and satellite MTrP irritability in the short term in older adults with nonspecific shoulder pain(48) -Based on a RCT involving 66 patients in Spain who were 65 years of age or older -Groups received either DN to both the latent MTrP and the active MTrP or to the active MTrP only -Outcome measures were the numeric pain rating scale, the pressure pain threshold on the anterior deltoid and extensor carpi radialis brevis latent MTrPs, and grip strength –Two treatments of TrP-DN  are as effective as two treatments of TrP manual therapy as a short-term  treatment of pain, disability, and ROM in patients with chronic mechanical neck pain, although TrP-DN  was more effective than TrP manual therapy in decreasing pressure pain thresholds over the cervical spine(35) -Based on an RCT with 94 patients conducted in Spain -Outcome measures were 11-point  numeric pain rating scale, cervical ROM, pressure point thresholds over C7 spinous process, and the Spanish version of the Northwick Park Neck Pain Questionnaire –DN plus exercise was not found to be superior to sham DN plus exercise in an RCT conducted in Australia in patients with chronic whiplash-associated  disorders (WAD)(36) -Eighty patients with chronic WAD (> 3 months) received either 6 weeks of DN plus exercise or 6 weeks of sham DN plus exercise -Outcome measures were the Neck Disability Index (NDI) and self-rated  recovery at baseline, 6 and 12 weeks, and 6 and 12 months by blinded assessor -Although DN plus exercise was better than sham DN plus exercise at 6 and 12 months, the treatment effects were small and not clinically worthwhile –TrP-DN  combined with traditional physical therapy is no more effective than traditional PT to improve shoulder ROM and upper extremity function following shoulder stabilization surgery(37) -Based on an RCT involving 39 patients conducted in the United States. Patients were randomized to either PT intervention or PT intervention+TrP-DN -No differences in groups were seen with ROM and pain subsets –DN may improve pain (measured by V AS), spasticity, and motor function in patients who have had a stroke(18) -Based on a systematic review and meta-analysis  of 7 studies –Deep dry needling (DDN) combined with stretching was more beneficial in treating nonspecific neck pain compared with stretching alone(43) -Based on an RCT study in Spain with 130 participants with nonspecific neck pain -Patients were randomized to either the DDN (n = 65) or stretching only group (n = 65) and treated 4x/week for 2 weeks -Pain intensity, neck ROM, neck muscle strength, and pain disability were measured at baseline, after 2 sessions, after intervention period, and at 15,30,90, and 180 days after intervention was completed -The authors found significant differences in all outcome measures (p < 0.001) and concluded that DDN combined with passive stretching is favorable to stretching alone

Temporomandibular joint (TMJ) –DN appears to be effective to relieve pain and tenderness of temporomandibular myofascial pain(22) -Based on a double-blind,  randomized, placebo-controlled  trial conducted in Turkey -A total of 52 subjects were randomized to receive DN or sham DN -Outcome measures included pressure algometry, V AS, and unassisted jaw opening without pain -Mean algometric values were significantly higher in the intervention group –A multimodal physical therapy management approach that includes TrP-DN  may decrease pain disability and increase maximal mouth opening in TMJ dysfunction(23) -Based on a prospective case series conducted in Spain  -Multimodal treatment consisted of mobilization with movement of the TMJ and cervical spine, thoracic spine manipulation, and masseter muscle TrP-DN -Outcome measures included Temporomandibular disorder (TMD) Disability Questionnaire, V AS, and maximal mouth opening -Patients who received multimodal treatment exhibited significant and clinical improvements in pain intensity, disability, and mouth opening

Knee –Inclusion of DN to the vastus medialis and vastus lateralis muscle in a multimodal program (manual therapy and exercise) did not improve outcomes for patients with patellofemoral pain (PFP)(49) -Based on an RCT of 60 patients with PFP in Spain -Treatments were once a week for 3 weeks -Outcome measures were the pain subscale of the Knee injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS; 0–100 scale), other subscales of the KOOS, the Knee Society Score, the International Knee Documentation Committee Subjective Knee Evaluation Form (IKDC), and the numeric pain-rating  scale –DN of lower limb MTrPs may prevent pain after total knee arthroplasty(24) -Based on a case series study conducted in Chile -For 4 weeks, 14 patients received DN to their lower extremity MTrPs from an experienced, trained PT once a week and participated in therapeutic exercise -The patients had improved walking speed, knee ROM, and pain levels following intervention

Ankle and foot –There is insufficient evidence to support the use of DN to improve symptoms in patients with ankle instability(28) –There is insufficient evidence to support the use of TrP-DN to reduce plantar heel pain when compared to sham TrP-DN(38,39,40)

Stroke –DDN was effective at decreasing localized pressure sensitivity and improved shoulder ROM, but did not show any significant difference in decreasing muscle spasticity for patients with stroke(44) -Based on an RCT in Spain of 20 patients with stroke. Patients were randomized to receive rehabilitation only or rehabilitation combined with DDN. Needles were placed along the upper trapezius, infraspinatus, subscapularis, and pectoralis major of the spastic shoulder -Intervention was applied 1x/week for 3 weeks -Spasticity was measured using the Modified Ashworth Scale -Results of the study concluded that DDN combined with rehabilitation can increase pressure pain threshold and shoulder AROM, but there were no significant differences in spasticity

Other applications –Authors of a 2016 retrospective study (N = 44) found that the use of ultrasound-guided  dry needling (USGDN) on patients with chronic regional pain syndrome showed significant improvements in co-contraction  of the agonist/antagonist muscle of the shoulder, resulting in increases in the DASH outcome scores in all 44 patients. By improving co-contraction of the agonist and antagonist muscles, the shoulder is able to move in a smooth motion, decreasing any friction that may occur in the joint(s).Patients were objectively measured using the DASH during pretreatment (mean = 85.11), 15 days (26.26), and 45 days (15.73), resulting in > 50% improvement after 50 days and 75% improvement after 45 days(42) –Authors of a 2016 systematic review found that DN can be effective at reducing pain in lower quarter trigger points, but did not affect overall function, QOL, depression, ROM, or strength(45) –DN was found to be noninferior to cortisone injection in reducing lateral hip pain in patients with greater trochanter pain syndrome and could be considered an alternative treatment(50) -Based on an RCT conducted in the United States on 50 hips; measurements were taken over 6 weeks -Primary outcome measure was the numeric pain-rating scale –DN was not found to increase extensibility of the hamstrings beyond stretching alone in patients with ROM deficits and no symptoms(51) -Based on an RCT conducted in the United States of 27 patients with limited hamstring extensibility –One session of DN was shown to increase vertical jump in healthy young adults(52) -Based on a study of 35 students in the United States  -Intervention group received DN to four sites on bilateral gastrocnemius muscles:two on the medial head and two on the lateral head. Sham group had needle casing pressed to skin but no needle was inserted -The DN group significantly increased vertical jump height (1.2 inches) over the sham group when tested right after intervention

See Description , Indications for procedure , and Guidelines for use of procedure , above . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Pain secondary to TrP activation _ _ Reduced function due to ankle joint pain and instabilityReduced pain, both local and referred _ _ Increased pressure pain threshold _ _ Deactivation of MTrP with increased ankle joint functionTherapeutic modalities _ DN _ _ _ DN combined with proprioceptive exerciseProgression will be unique to each patient and underlying diagnosisProvide instruction for complementary exercises to be performed safely at home Reduced mobility secondary to MTrP; reduced ability to perform work dutiesIncreased ROM/ flexibility _ Improved functional mobility _ Return to workTherapeutic modalities _ DNProgression will be unique to each patient and underlying diagnosisProvide instruction for complementary exercises to be performed safely at home Spasticity, generalized pain, decreased plantar pressures on affected side in patient with strokeDecreased spasticity, generalized pain, and increased plantar pressure on affected side(44)Therapeutic modalities:  DNProgression will be unique to each patient and underlying diagnosisProvide instruction for complementary exercises to be performed safely at home .

desired therapeutic outcomes: Decreased pain–V AS, numeric pain rating scale, pressure pain threshold
Improved function–Standardized functional outcome assessments such as:-Foot and Ankle Ability Measure (FAAM)(28)-Oswestry Disability Index(32)-Constant-Murley  score(37)-WOMAC(24)

patient education: Patient information:  Many therapy practice websites and training institutes provide information on the DN procedure The APTA provides the following information, “Dry Needling by a Physical Therapist: What You Should Know,” for consumers interested in learning more about DN:https://www.moveforwardpt.com/resources/detail/dry-needling-by-physical-therapist-what-you-should#.Vj_KZeIYHPf

Therapist information Position and protocol papers regarding use of DN by therapists are available online. Some papers include: –Information (downloadable pdf files) on DN from FSBPT, including list of competencies: https://www.fsbpt.org/ Search.aspx?q=dry%20needling Information regarding courses for therapists may be obtained by searching for continuing education or advanced training courses available in a specific country or location Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
